Articles.Content: PersistentRotation is a mod that fits into a short list of mods that enhance KSPÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s physics. When installed this mod allows vessels to continue rotating, even under timewarp or when not selected. It can even make your vessels keep a persistent relative position, for example keeping an antenna pointed down at Kerbin consistently. Download links and such can be found in the [http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/113507](**forum thread**.

I highly recommend this mod. Be warned though that it leads to new ways to have `fun` for example I had one probe around Minmus that was rotating at just the wrong speed which meant that the time it took for the panels to face the sun was the same as it took to face the panel away from the sun due to craft rotation and I had a fully functioning dead probe... It was great.

As far as waiting until all physics bugs are gone, I think that would impose too harsh a criteria and our wait would become eternal. I`d rather have this stock and deal with rotation bugs than use insta-stop.

I would imagine that it would just be another difficulty setting so it could be turned off temporarily for `problem craft`in the cheat menu.

Oh cool, I never tried this mod so didn't know it could also do "point at X". I thought it just kept the current rotation of a craft.

I always thought it pants that my ScanSat satellites didn't keep the sensors pointed at the planet. Will have to try this now!

Sorry. Fan of the insta-stop. Sometimes it's the only way to regain control of a craft which may or may not be pilot error. The only thing I would like to see is the ability to keep a craft facing a set direction, such as pointing an antenna. Outside of that, I could care less if my craft is spinning or not at warp.
Is there a performance hit with this mod? It seems like continuously calculating the orientation of multiple vehicles might use up a lot of cycles - or maybe it doesn't, anyone have any insight?
I don't think it calculates continuously, rather remembers what the rotation speed/axis was, and applies it when the ship is loaded.

> 
> I don't think it calculates continuously, rather remembers what the rotation speed/axis was, and applies it when the ship is loaded.

That is precisely what it does. It saves the craft's rotation speed in persistence and then reapplies it when time warp stops or when the craft is loaded. Assuming it is well coded (I haven't looked) it should have very little performance hit. It does not calculate physics while on rails. Further more, any rotation that would have happened, were the ship not in on-rails mode, will not have applied. 

So the end result is the craft retains it's rotation speed but it will not be facing the same direction coming out of time warp as it would be if you never entered time warp, because it still doesn't rotate in time warp. 

Still, it's good enough for most people.
